Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: A Total Evidence Phylogeny of the Ants
Award.AbstractNarration:
Researchers at the American Museum of Natural History are using 20 to 100 million year old amber specimens (fossilized tree resin) from deposits around the world to understand how ants evolved from an ancestral solitary wasp into the diverse and abundant group of social creatures they are today. Fossil and modern specimens in the AMNH, as well as in museums in Russia, England, France, and Brazil are being studied using X-Ray-based 3d reconstruction and traditional light microscopy. These data are being combined with published DNA sequences from modern ants and analyzed to produce a clear pattern of evolution through time and the major physiological, behavioral, and ecological features that aided in diversification.

Ants are one of the greatest success stories in nature. At present there are over 12,000 species of ants, with an estimated biomass at least equal to all humans. This project seeks to fundamentally inform other studies relating to behavior, ecology, systematics, and developmental biology by detailing relationships among these model organisms in a novel way. In addition, because ants are very familiar and recognizable to the public, there is tremendous potential for outreach. The co-PI has and will continue to educate K-12 students and the museum-going public using ants as a model for understanding biological concepts at large.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Today, with over 12,000 described species, ants comprise a significant ecological component of nearly all vegetated terrestrial environments – but this was not always the case. Through comparative study of specimens at museums in the US and abroad, as well as high resolution CT-scanning techniques, substantial progress has been made toward understanding the fossil history of ants. By generating novel datasets and combing them with others already published, the earliest ants known from ~100 million year old amber, as well as fossils as young as the Miocene (20 million years old) have been contextualized with respect to modern species through study of morphology and DNA sequences. Results suggest that early ants were distinct from their modern relatives, highly social, diverse, and, ultimately, bound for extinction. While the earliest ants possess many innovations exhibited by modern ants, they are a very minor part of fossil assemblages worldwide and ultimately “replaced” by familiar, living groups in the fossil record. This raises important questions regarding differential success among early and modern lineages. In addition, the role of fossils in molecular (DNA) datasets was evaluated, with implications for future studies relating to the nature of paleontological integration. A particularly contentious fossil species from the Caribbean was identified as a close relative of an Australasian group, suggesting an ancient range extending through Antarctica prior to glaciation – a hypothesis only recovered through direct fossil study and analysis. These results were presented at two national meetings, and in preparation for publication. The co-PI connected this research with K-12 students at the American Museum of Natural History and elsewhere in the New York City area through demonstrations and interactive talks with the aim of generating broad interest in paleontology and the scientific process at large.
